title: An Insight on Wide-Area Networks Part 2
historical_context: This article is part of a series exploring the development and significance of early wide-area networks in the 1980s, providing insights into their architecture and operational principles.
target_audience: Network engineers, historians of technology, hackers, and anyone interested in the evolution of computer networks.
short_summary: This article provides an overview of several early wide-area networks, including BITNET, MFENET, UUCP, and USENET, detailing their functionalities, technologies, and the communities they served.
summary:
In this second part of the series on wide-area networks, Jester Sluggo delves into the workings of BITNET, MFENET, UUCP, and USENET. BITNET, established in 1981, was designed for interuniversity communication, utilizing RSCS software on IBM systems and allowing for electronic mail and file transfers. The article highlights the rapid expansion of BITNET and its eventual integration with ARPANET and CSNET, showcasing its importance in academic communication. MFENET, on the other hand, was tailored for the Department of Energy's supercomputing needs, emphasizing the challenges of specialized protocols and the need for migration to more universal standards like TCP-IP. 

The discussion extends to UUCP and USENET, which emerged from the UNIX community to facilitate email and news sharing among users. Sluggo notes the decentralized nature of these networks, relying on mutual cooperation among participants, which contributed to their growth and resilience. The article serves as a historical snapshot of the early networking landscape, illustrating how these systems laid the groundwork for modern internet protocols and services.
